posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
How does your team primarily write commands?

Hey everyone! I’m running this poll for the third year in a row (2024, 2023), to track the adoption/consumption of the (now no longer new) “v2” Commands API. Recall that commands can be created in two ways: you can write a subclass of Command with overrides for each lifecycle method (initialize, execute, isFinished, end) containing your command logic, and then construct an instance of that subclass; or you can pass your code as a callback (e.g., by method reference or lambda function) to a factory function or Command subclass constructor. As explained in earlier threads, WPILib has been moving towards a more-functional/less OO-driven architecture for several years now—but as past polls have shown, legacy subclass interactions are still quite popular. Please share how you primarily interacted with the Command-based framework this year. Feel free to respond with further details below.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked:
We started mostly inline (see the registerXXXX methods in RobotContainer here), but when my students needed to make Named Commands for use with pathplanner, they for one reason or another made explicit command classes for each (I was busy doing volunteer stuff during the time they developed this).

This year, our subsystems were all either finite state machines or moving one control loop to a setpoint, so commands were simple calls to change the state of the subsystem, and most control code was handled in our subsystem periodic methods.

I will try to remember to pick their brains on why they went that way and bring the feedback back to the thread.

(In the past, we always did explicit classes but this year tried to stay inline for commands.)

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: We were mostly inline, with a couple of explicit classes for aligning content to a reef pole.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Noah Zemlin
posts.cooked: Our approach last year was similar to yours, often depending on who was writing the code. We used 100% explicit subclasses last year. For next year, I plan to guide the programmers toward using nearly 100% inline or factory methods, except for highly complex commands that require a lot of logic, such as combined auto-aligning and scoring, which we used this year. Reducing the number of XYZCommand.java files from 1,000 made a significant improvement in code clarity and ease of tracing.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: We primarily use inline code snippets for our basic commands but often embed complex logic within them, making our default approach rely more on subclasses. This allows us the convenience of referencing commands within command groups, though I'm uncertain if composing such groups with anonymous inner classes would be feasible.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: We started using command factories this year (thanks @bovlb!) for nearly all our commands, except for a few long sequences that had their own files. This approach saved us a lot of time compared to writing out entire files, and binding commands to buttons became much simpler and cleaner. Our robot this year didn’t require a state machine-style control system, which made it incredibly easy to operate using a few preset sequences. This is one of the areas where command factories really shine, so I’m looking forward to using this convention even more in the future!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: To compose command groups using anonymous inner classes in C#, factory methods can be employed to create instances without directly instantiating them using the `new` keyword. This approach helps encapsulate the creation logic, making it easier to manage and test. By utilizing factory methods, often part of frameworks like Dagger or dependency injection containers, you can define command groups as anonymous inner classes inline, streamlining your code and promoting better separation of concerns.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Our students found that managing many small files made it easier to keep track of the numerous layers of both parallel and sequential tasks they worked on this year, as well as various parallel experiments they conducted. Another minor concern was logging active commands, which required a name and appropriate logging within collections. As we understood, neither inline factories nor WPILib supported this functionality.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: This year, we employed strictly factory methods, which worked well for the most part. However, a layer of organization had to be reinvented, unlike the previous subclass approach. For instance, all our multi-subsystem factories were consolidated into the Autos class along with other utility functions for determining selected scoring operations. Several factories required class-specific objects such as Trapezoid Profiles or SwerveRequests, which were defined adjacent to the factory methods. While adequate comments helped maintain organization, this arrangement led to the Drivebase class accumulating a significant amount of complex drivebase-only command logic, making it challenging to navigate. Consequently, the Autos class became cumbersome to review due to its extensive content.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: This is my first year running programming for our team. Initially, looking at our 2024 code, I found command classes seemed more challenging to use compared to inline commands. However, after further review, I realized command classes are actually more readable. We primarily used inline commands until right before competition, as our systems were still being developed and we hadn’t extensively tested them beyond basic functionality. This approach became problematic when I noticed that many inline commands weren’t functioning correctly because of insufficient command-based knowledge. Switching to command classes solved this issue, and they worked well for us. While I’m still learning some aspects of them, I find them significantly simpler to use overall. Commands.runOnce() was particularly useful in our code. My initial stance on this topic evolved over the season, but due to the number of remaining inline commands in our codebase, I ended up answering questions inline instead.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked:
One challenge I'm facing is determining whether to place certain methods within Subsystems or as static methods in the `RobotContainer` or another global class. While organizing methods into Subsystems seems efficient, it becomes cumbersome when needing to control multiple Subsystems simultaneously. On the other hand, creating a monolithic class containing all commands can lead to complexity as the project evolves. 

I recall that WPILib has specific recommendations regarding this structure. If my commands interact with more than one Subsystem, they may be doing too much and should instead be composed from separate Subsystems. This approach keeps each command focused and simplifies management. However, using two or three Subsystems in most commands might still be acceptable, especially if documented well in a comprehensive file. Striking a balance between organization and simplicity seems key, possibly incorporating both Subsystems and composite commands for multi-Subsystem operations. Consulting the official documentation or community examples would provide further clarity on best practices.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Subsystems should expose their contracts as command factories in subsystem scope. Composite commands using multiple subsystems can be defined in RobotContainer, or else in some command factory helper class into which you inject the subsystems.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked: As explained in earlier discussions, WPILib has been transitioning toward a more functional and less object-oriented architecture over the years, though many users still prefer legacy subclass interactions. We’ve moved toward a functional approach with suppliers and light state machines driven by commands, but breaking away from long-standing habits has been challenging. While we understand that triggers are often highlighted as the preferred method, we haven’t yet found a clear, practical example to guide our transition effectively.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The RapidReactCommandBot example is the most architecturally up-to-date of the official examples at the moment. I know some people are working on improving the documentation this summer, which might change things.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: We only received commands from subsystem files, but everything was managed through an overarching “superstructure” class (finite state machine) that extensively used Triggers to explicitly define state transitions. This approach, inspired by Team 8033, is highly recommended.

Our programmers and I love inline commands, our robot from 24’ and this year didn’t need a state machine, so everything could be programmed as sequences. They also used them in our NamedCommands for auto routines. Our programmers typically create basic commands as subclasses, like RunIntake or ShootCoral, etc., and then use the Command Factories API to chain them together like a sequence. For example: joystick.x().onTrue(new IntakeAndPivot(collector, .7).until(() => !collector.hasAlgae()).andThen(new PivotBack(collector))). However, this made our RobotContainer class quite large and clunky to read, and it got even more complicated when our lead programmer tried coding an auto-align to the reef, so we moved the complex stuff into its own Command class instead.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: We switched to a mostly trigger-based architecture this year, consolidating various actions and measurements into a single file containing numerous triggers. These triggers represent any robotic actions or reactions we want the system to perform. Our commands are typically defined within subsystems and bound to these triggers through a bindCommands() method activated during initialization. This approach was heavily inspired by SpectrumLib, as demonstrated in the linked video.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: another minor issue for us was wanting to be able to log the active command, so it needs a name. I recommend using the `withName` decorator from [the WPIJ2 Command documentation](https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj2/command/Command.html#withName(java.lang.String)). Use this decorator liberally in your command factories and whenever you are combining commands.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The text you've provided appears to be a mix of HTML code and technical discussion about programming practices. Here's the cleaned-up version:

As I understand it, neither inline factories nor the WPILib collections seem to handle what you're referring to. However, you can achieve this by using `Commands.idle().withName("Busywork")`, which needs to be placed at the end of your composition.

This was the first year we really focused on the Trigger+Command factory interface, and it worked well. It was cleaner than previous years' void-based `doSomething()` interfaces. For simple commands, it reduced syntax, and for more complex ones, like trapezoidal profiles, it provided a centralized place to manage internal states.

Our main challenge during this transition was making it clear when commands should end. We learned the hard way that most factories shouldn't end by default. Instead, you typically need to add a condition or use a secondary factory as a shortcut.

The only unresolved issue we encountered was the lack of a robust state machine framework compatible with our command flow patterns. This became a summer project to address.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: Have you checked out the 8033 approach? I really liked it and found it really easy to implement. You can find examples in their code or ours on our platform this year.
